newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries end lower before wage inflation data.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries end lower before wage inflation data.

text.p: Prices of U.S. government securities ended lower for the fourth straight session on Monday, as market players worried a key U.S. labor cost gauge due Tuesday would show inflation clouds gathering.

"We've been down four days in a row, mainly on more anxiety ahead of the Tuesday number," said Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at I.D.E.A., referring to the government's fourth-quarter Employment Cost Index (ECI) that financial markets have been awaiting.

"We're down in anticipation of higher employment costs and strong fourth-quarter GDP (Gross Domestic Product)," said Chase Securities chief economist Charles Lieberman. "People are adjusting their positions to hedge against those risks."
Economists polled by Reuters predicted, on average, that the fourth-quarter ECI would be up 0.9 percent after a more-moderate-than-expected 0.6-percent third-quarter gain.
The so-called advance fourth-quarter GDP estimate, due on Friday, will be up 3.9 percent, according to the Reuters poll.
The 6-1/2-percent 30-year benchmark Treasury bond ended at 94-14/32, down 21/32, on Monday.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond closing yield of 6.94 percent was the highest since September 24, when it ended at 6.99 percent.

Besides the pervasive anxiety about the Employment Cost Index, a break below support at 109-26 on the March T-bond futures contract triggered selling, participants said. Also, heavy corporate issuance weighed on the debt markets.

"Important technical support was pierced, there was a lot of corporate issuance today and a lot more is coming and some longs finally gave up," said Carey Leahey, senior vice president at Lehman Government Securities Inc.

A Tenet Health Care Corp $2.0 billion high-yield bond issue, the unloading of mortgage-backed securities by NationsBank Corp and the need to distribute the two- and five-year notes that the Treasury sold last week all weighed on a market where sellers had to look hard for players willing to buy before Tuesday's ECI report, strategists said.
"People are contending with supply and asking themselves (at what price) do we want to own these," said Stiles.
Nervousness was also present in the stock market, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell for the fourth day in a row, off 35.79 points to 6660.69.
In the stock market, analysts talked of the increased competition to stocks posed by bonds offering yields of nearly seven percent.

In the bond market, participants said a fourth-quarter ECI rise of 1.0 percent or higher could easily push the 30-year bond yield above seven percent. But they also said falling prices and rising yields in the bond market had largely discounted the consensus ECI forecast of up 0.9 percent.
"To see more selling, you'd have to see a sizable ECI increase," said Kevin Flanagan, first vice president and money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds.
"Otherwise, you'll hear people talking that we're oversold right now," he said.
The market also could not get a boost from a fall in December existing home sales to an annualized rate of 3.87 million from a revised annualized rate of 4.01 million in November.
"The bullish impact was undermined because the inventory of unsold homes plunged to 5.1 months from 6.7 months and the year-over-year median home price rose 4.3 percent," said Stiles.

At the short end of the maturity curve, the three-month Treasury bill rate closed up two basis points at 5.05 percent. Six-month and year-bill rates rose three basis points each to 5.16 percent and 5.33 percent, respectively.

Two-year notes closed down 3/32 at 99-18/32, yielding 6.11 percent. In the intermediate sector, the five-year note traded off 7/32 at 99-6/32 to yield 6.44 percent. The ten-year note closed down 11/32 at 99-24/32, yielding 6.68 percent.
(( -- North American Treasury Desk 212-859-1679 ))
